East St. Louis District 189 will begin assessing students using NWEA MAP Growth assessments on Monday, August 24, 2020. Teachers will be sending communications to families and students with specifics on how and when to join the testing session.

NWEA MAP Growth assessments this year will be administered to students as follows:
- READING: Grades 1 through 10
- MATH: Grades 1 through 10
- SCIENCE: Grades 3 through 8

This test is not a traditional test like you may have taken in the past. Some important things to keep in mind:
- Students cannot pass or fail this test!
- This test WILL NOT affect grades.
- This test helps teachers.

The Fall Testing Window is scheduled to end on Friday, September 11, 2020. Be sure to check in with teachers if you have any questions related to this process.

Casey Schardan shares, "My first year of teaching has been filled with so many different emotions, and I can hardly believe it is coming to an end. My first grade students are the brightest, most strong willed, resilient students in all of the land. Each and every day they pushed me outside of my comfort zone and challenged me in ways I didn't know were even possible. Going into this year, the one idea I held onto was having a classroom where students weren't afraid to take risks, make mistakes, and enjoy learning. I believe together we created that environment. I am thankful for the Teacher Residency Program who continued to support me in this first year - challenging me to step outside of the box and be reflective in my practice. It is comforting knowing you have leaders in your corner who want to see you succeed, help you grow in your practice, and be better for your students. Year one...in the books."

- Trouble breathing
- Persistent pain or pressure in the chest
- New confusion or inability to arouse
- Bluish lips or face

On Jan. 26-27, Fifteen student Peace Warriors from East St. Louis Senior High School and Wyvetter Young Alternative Center traveled to Chicago to meet the Peace Warriors at North Lawndale College Prep (NCLP). The students learned about each other’s experiences as Peace Warriors, shared the similarities and differences between Chicago and East St. Louis, and talked about how to spread peace in their schools. District 189 Peace Warriors also cheered on the boys basketball team and joined with NCLP Peace Warriors to lead attendees in the African Clap. District 189 Peace Warriors left Chicago with new friends and allies in nonviolence across the state!

Peace Warriors are student leaders who use the principles of non-violence advanced by Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. to positively impact school culture and reduce violence in their schools and communities. The District 189 Peace Warriors program is a partnership with Join Hands ESL.
